home.title: AI Ethics Suitcase
home.subtitle: Interactive application for exploring linear classification

intro.headerTitle: Welcome to the AI Ethics Suitcase!

tour.0: Welcome to the AI Ethics Suitcase! This is the introduction level where you will learn about the interface and basics of visualization using charts. You may skip this tutorial if you are already familiar with these concepts.
tour.1: You are currently on Level -1, which is the introduction level. There are 8 more levels.
tour.2: This is the legend that explains the data points and classification.
tour.3: This is the chart that visualizes the relationship between Study Time and Screen Time.
tour.4: This is the X-axis representing Study Time in minutes.
tour.5: This is the Y-axis representing Screen Time in minutes.
tour.6: This is a data point for a student who passed, with study time of 150 minutes and screen time of 300 minutes.
tour.7: This is a data point for a student who failed, with study time of 100 minutes and screen time of 200 minutes.

alerts.invalidIntersection: The line does not properly intersect the graph boundaries. Please retry.

stages.0: We want to classify a simple dataset of 4 students first by drawing a line that seperates Pass and Fail students. To start, click to select the first point of the line
stages.1: Now click the second point to draw the classification line
stages.2: Drag the black circles to adjust the line, then click one of the regions to classify as Pass
stages.3: Adjust your classifier by rotating the line or creating a new one (by clicking 2 points). When satisfied, click 'Next' to continue.
stages.4: Complete! You can now see the classification results. In the next level we will introduce the new terms and how to estimate the performance of a classifier.

instructions.0: How to measure the accuracy of a linear classifier?

tour.0: We will now explain the terms used to measure the accuracy of a linear classifier.
tour.1: The classification results show the counts of true positives, true negatives, false positives, and false negatives.
tour.2: A linear classifier divides this chart into 2 parts, the left region being classified as Fail and the right being classified as Pass
tour.3: This student passed and our classifier classified them as Pass. This is a True Positive.
tour.4: This student failed and our classifier classified them as Fail. This is a True Negative.
tour.5: This student failed however our classifier classified them as Pass. This is a False Positive.
tour.6: This student passed however our classifier classified them as Fail. This is a False Negative.
tour.7: The accuracy of a classifier is the ratio of correctly classified over total samples.

stages.0: Click to select the first point of the line
stages.1: Now click the second point to draw the classification line
stages.2: Drag the black circles to adjust the line, then click one of the regions to classify as Pass
stages.3: Adjust your classifier by rotating the line or creating a new one. When satisfied, click 'Next' to continue.
stages.4: Complete! You can now see the classification results. You can compare your classifier with the best classifier found by AI.
stages.5: Compare your classifier with the best classifier. Both results are shown side by side.

stages.0: Click to select the first point of the line
stages.1: Now click the second point to draw the classification line
stages.2: Drag the black circles to adjust the line, then click one of the regions to classify as Pass
stages.3: Adjust your classifier by rotating the line or creating a new one. When satisfied, click 'Next' to continue.
stages.4: Complete! You can now see the classification results. You can compare your classifier with the best classifier found by AI.
stages.5: Compare your classifier with the best classifier. Both results are shown side by side.
stages.6: Now toggle between already seen data and the unseen data. Notice how performance may differ on unseen data!

stages.0: Start drawing a curve starting outside the graph area and ending outside the graph area
stages.1: Click an area to classify it as Pass
stages.2: You may create a new classifier by drawing again. When satisfied, click 'Next' to continue.
stages.3: Complete! You can now see the classification results.
stages.4: Now toggle between seen and unseen  data. Notice how performance may differ on unseen data!
